bestBHT.bht: Without any preparation, Jesus remained in the boat as they set off, with other boats accompanying them. They took Jesus as he was, without any previous arrangements. These other boats were likely filled with people who wanted to be close to Jesus. As they journeyed across the lake, Jesus laid himself at the stern, his head resting on a pillow. It seems that these other boats were meant to witness the miracle that would happen later on.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Without any preparation, and without so much as leaving the vessel, out of which He had been all day teaching.
Other little ships—with passengers, probably, wishing to accompany Him.
Marvin Vincent: Even as he was in the ship. Rev., boat. Just as he was, in the boat in which he was then sitting. Mark adds the detail about the accompanying boats.
Philip Schaff: They did not send them away, but left them.
He was already in the boat, and they set off at once.
These other boats were probably separated from them during the subsequent gale.
Archibald T. Robertson: Even as he was (ως ην). Vulgate, ita ut erat. Bengel says: sine apparatu. That is, they take Jesus along (παραλαμβανουσιν) without previous preparation.
Other boats (αλλα πλοια). This detail also is given only by Mark.
Some people had got into boats to get close to Jesus. There was a crowd even on the lake.
John Gill: They took him even as he was in the ship.
He laid himself... placing himself at the stern, and laying his head upon a pillow there, and so they carried him.

There were also with him other little ships; or boats, that were in company with that, in which Christ was... these seem to be ordered in providence to be in company, that they might be witnesses of the after miracle.
John Wesley: They take him as he was in the vessel — They carried him immediately in the same vessel from which he had been preaching to the people.

bhtAttempts.bht: Without any preparation, Jesus was taken as he was, without so much as leaving the boat where he had been teaching all day. Other boats accompanied him, most likely with passengers wanting to be close to him. They did not send the other boats away, but left them, setting off at once. These other boats would later be separated from them during the subsequent gale. It is worth noting that Mark is the only gospel that mentions these additional boats, which were ordered in providence to witness the miraculous events that would unfold later.

These other boats would later be separated from them during the subsequent gale. Mark is the only gospel that mentions these additional boats, which were ordered in providence to witness the miraculous events that would unfold later.

Without any preparation, Jesus remained in the boat as they set off, with other boats accompanying them. They took Jesus as he was, without any previous arrangements. These other boats were likely filled with people who wanted to be close to Jesus. As they journeyed across the lake, Jesus laid himself at the stern, his head resting on a pillow. It seems that these other boats were meant to witness the miracle that would happen later on. So, without delay, Jesus and his disciples embarked on the boat, accompanied by a flotilla of other vessels, taking in Jesus just as he was, from the boat he had been teaching on earlier.
